# Writeup
The challenge description hints, that one of the primes is very big, ergo the other prime must be very small. Therefore, one of them can be bruteforced. 
```python
#find factor p
for i in range(2, 1000000):
    if N % i == 0:
        print("Factor found: " + str(i))
        break
```
The other prime can be calculated by simple division. The rest of the calculation follows the normal procedure.
```python
from Crypto.Util.number import inverse

N = 

e = 65537

m = 

''' find factor p
for i in range(2, 1000000):
    if N % i == 0:
        print("Factor found: " + str(i))
        break
'''

p = 622751
q = N / p

phi = (p-1)*(q-1)


d = inverse(e,phi)
decrypted = pow(m,d,N)
print(hex(decrypted)[2:])
```
# Prevention
Both primes should be carefully chosen. Both should be big enough that you cannot bruteforce one of them.
